whose construction will be very easy to accomplish: since it is not necessary to make it from polished and squared stones: but it is sufficient for it to be either earthen or wooden because of the weakness and scarcity of weapons of the natives. Nevertheless it would be better to construct it from earth with a wooden roof covered with tiles because of the danger of combustion. For to do this would pertain to the prudence of the leader of the ambassadors of our kings so that future dangers and inconveniences may be prevented: and therefore it is better to forestall in advance: than after the outcome etc. As we said above. For one should not immediately trust foreign and unknown nations: although they may display signs of love, peace and courtesy. Although concerning our Indian peoples, before they knew us from our works, there was nothing at all for us to fear from them: since they knew how to carry nothing feigned, nothing deceitful toward us inwardly or outwardly: but with simple heart, with great admiration, joy and eagerness, with a certain paternal humanity, wonderful hospitality, with every kind of benefits they received us and treated us etc.
Part 9
Exhortation by gentle and sweet word etc.

¶ Namely, that in some suitable place they may gather together to hear
those things which are of the faith etc.

This part is sufficiently evident from the proof of the preceding matters, especially those (namely) humble greeting and address: and exemplary conduct and timely notification, quiet, gentle, friendly, most modest and conciliatory of the spirits of the hearers, patient etc.

¶ By a similar consideration the subsequent part is covered (namely) the preaching of the faith, distinct, discreet and regular according to the form established by Christ: so that the desired effect (that is) the conversion of those souls with divine help may follow through their entry into the most holy Catholic Church, voluntarily having received the sacrament of holy baptism.
¶ Part 10
¶ Information, by the same heralds of the faith, concerning the title of our kings etc.
¶ That this information concerning the title is necessary is proved

first thus: one alleging a singular title according to the laws must prove it even if he is a son, since there is a presumption in favor of the universal heir l. siue possidetis and Baldus there C. de probationibus

But on behalf of our kings is alleged a singular title, foreign, new and remarkable as regards those peoples. Those peoples indeed and their kings presume, indeed they know and we know that they are the true lords and just possessors of that world.

Therefore it is necessary that the title which our kings claim to have to the dominion or jurisdiction of those lands be proved to them on behalf of our kings: and they should be fully taught concerning the title.
¶ The consequence is clear with the Major premise.

The Minor is proved: because any possessor is presumed to believe himself owner Cynus in l. cum alienum C. de lega
Bartholus in l. 1. si de momem. posse fue. appel. 1 colu. verb. extra no.
For a possessor is held as owner if he possesses as owner
gloss, Bartholus and the doctors in l. quidam in fine ff. de conditionibus institutionum

¶ Secondly it is proved thus: the burden of proof lies on him who asserts or claims
l. actor C. de probationibus
and l. ei qui ff. eo titulo and
l. qui accusare C. de
edendo
Likewise the agent and whoever alleges or acts must prove what he alleges d. l. actor and Cynus, Bartholus and Baldus there which is true unless he has a presumption prose l. ei incumbit and
Bartholus there ff. de probationibus, especially a special one l. cum indebito eo titulo.
Likewise if the plaintiff is not in quasi-possession of the right which he asserts l. circa eum per Bartholum eo titulo. Likewise it is true even if the defendant has violent possession. d. l. circa eum and l. vis eius and Baldus there in the words I ask here whether the agent C. de probationibus.

¶ But our kings in this business do not have a presumption in their favor with respect to those peoples, nor are they in quasi-possession of the right which they assert themselves to have: Those peoples however and the whole world are not in violent possession but in proper, due, true, natural and peaceful possession.
Therefore the burden of proving what they assert lies upon our kings. And consequently they ought to teach concerning the title to prove and establish their claim. The consequence is clear.

¶ Moreover it is a general maxim that
whoever seeks dominion in any thing: it is necessary that he prove it
C. de rei vendi. doce et de alienatione iudicii l. 1
and
Innocent in C. inter quatuor de maioritate et obedientia.

¶ Again, thirdly thus: when someone seeks some debt with the debtor denying it, proof lies upon the one seeking. Particularly when the claim is not founded by the adversary: because a negative should not be proved by the one denying but by the adversary in the said case, namely when his claim is not founded Baldus in l. si ex cantione 2 columna

But our kings if they should seek a debt, namely obedience and subjection from those peoples of the Indian world: and they themselves deny it as they rightly can since they are free, as is evident from what has been said and will be more clearly evident below, nor do our kings have their claim founded, but those peoples do. Therefore the negative should be proved by our kings. But this means teaching concerning the title.
Therefore our kings are bound to teach and give proof to such peoples concerning the title which they claim to have to the universal dominion and sovereignty of that world.

¶ Fourthly it is proved by argument from the greater: for if one having possession when he has contrary right is compelled to show title, therefore much
better and more forcefully one who is known to have had hitherto neither right nor possession.

For wherever right resists someone wishing to claim some thing for himself, especially to the prejudice of another: it is necessary to show and teach concerning the title, as in one wishing to prescribe, as is the case in c. 1, de prescriptione lib. 6 and this even if he has possession of the thing without which prescription cannot occur de prescriptione c. illud 16 q. § potest and in regula sine possessione lib. 6

To our purpose a text sufficiently fitting and notable is found in C. cum persone de priuilegiis lib. 6 where
subjects of a bishop if they say that they are exempt from the bishop because of the resistance of right which they have against themselves: it is necessary before all else to show the title of their exemption, and if they do not show it and they try to prove prescription, with the proof of prescription preceding: since by common law the ordinaries, their claim being thus founded, can use their jurisdiction freely over them until they have given full proof concerning the prescription, although those are in possession of the exemption. From which that text infers according to some that during a pending suit that possessor against whom common law works can be disturbed and violently expelled, just like one who possesses by force or stealth or by precarious right
Thus says Ancharanus there in the 11th notable point.

Therefore someone is compelled to show by what title he possesses or seeks some thing when it is contrary to common law: otherwise he will be able to be deprived of it if he possesses, or his petition repudiated if he seeks to possess. As is evident from the aforesaid, and
Baldus holds in l. 2, 2 columna C. quomodo et quando iudi.
saying that one who claims the title of his possession: whom
Alvarotus reports and follows in c. 1 in prin. de controuertis inuestigandum

If therefore someone existing in possession of a thing, when he has law against himself, is compelled to show title, it follows by stronger reason that our Kings of Spain are bound to show the title by which they would be supported in seeking from those peoples and nations to be received as Lords and thus obedience etc., since they are known to have had hitherto neither possession nor property nor any right in and to those kingdoms and peoples: and consequently all common law, natural, human and
divine resists them. Which nevertheless entirely favors and supports the inhabitants and dwellers of that world who justly possess those things.
For it is greater to have possession of a thing and to have legitimately acquired right: than merely to claim title to a thing in another's property.

¶ To the purpose is what Panormitanus says: after
Innocent in c. post electionem de concessione prebende
that against one acting in a possessory manner, exception is made of defect of power in the one conferring or in the one electing. And such exception is admitted as in c. cum olim de causa possessionis et proprietatis. For possession should not be given to anyone which he never had: unless his legitimate title is first established l. fi. C. de edicto diui adriani tollendo

Therefore our kings never had possession or property of that world before that world was discovered. Likewise all those peoples with their lords and kings can by the best right make exception of defect of power in the Supreme Pontiff that he might have handed over to the dominion and jurisdiction and servitude of another foreign king: great Kings and peoples and nations and free kingdoms possessing freedom by the law of nature and of nations.

Whence it is evident: that our kings are bound to teach those nations concerning the title which they put forward so that the natural and juridical order may be preserved, as is said in the conclusion.
